abstract.p: Jared Palmer and Arantxa Sanchez-Vicario defeat Max Mirnyi and Anna Kournikova in mixed doubles championship at United States Open (S)

block.p: Jared Palmer was tired and depressed. He and his Olympic partner, Alex O'Brien, who were seeded third, had just lost their men's doubles semifinal match in a crushing third-set tie breaker, 6-4, 3-6, 7-6 (7), to the unseeded team of Max Mirnyi and Lleyton Hewitt.
''I was pretty disappointed,'' Palmer said. ''I was tired. It's hard because there aren't too many opportunities to be in a Grand Slam final.''

Jared Palmer was tired and depressed. He and his Olympic partner, Alex O'Brien, who were seeded third, had just lost their men's doubles semifinal match in a crushing third-set tie breaker, 6-4, 3-6, 7-6 (7), to the unseeded team of Max Mirnyi and Lleyton Hewitt.
''I was pretty disappointed,'' Palmer said. ''I was tired. It's hard because there aren't too many opportunities to be in a Grand Slam final.''
During a break between matches, friends told him not to bungle another one.
''They gave me a little pep talk,'' he said. ''My girlfriend reminded me that I still had a chance to win a Grand Slam title.''
And he did. Palmer and Arantxa Sanchez-Vicario defeated Mirnyi and Anna Kournikova, 6-4, 6-3, yesterday in the mixed doubles championship in Arthur Ashe Stadium.
With Sanchez-Vicario stalking the baseline, Palmer played the net, slamming angled volleys.
''Arantxa has such a good return that I was able to do some stuff up at the net,'' Palmer said. ''I think that was the key.''

Sanchez-Vicario and Palmer first broached the idea of playing together at Wimbledon this year. At the beginning of the Open, Sanchez-Vicario almost decided against it, because she was nursing a sore ankle.
''I'm glad she decided to play,'' Palmer said.
